column1: Application to stay Court of Appeals' judgment and mandate affirming applicants' criminal contempt convictions for violating District Court's injunction is denied. The Court of Appeals apparently has granted a stay with respect to other individuals who were convicted of criminal contempt for violation of the same injunction; it is uncertain whether applicants have sought a stay from the Court of Appeals pending this Court's disposition of their petition for certiorari; and this Court has granted certiorari in a related case in which applicants' asserted basis for a stay will be reviewed.  Accordingly
column2: it is the better exercise of discretion to require applicants to apply to the Court of Appeals for a stay pending this Court's disposition of their petition for certiorari.

column1: Under the New Jersey homicide statutes
column2: life imprisonment is the mandatory punishment for defendants convicted by a jury of first-degree murder
column3: while a term of not more than 30 years is the punishment for second-degree murder.  Trials to the court and guilty pleas are not allowed in murder cases
column4: but a plea of non vult is allowed.  If such a plea is accepted
column5: the judge need not decide whether the murder is first or second degree
column6: but the punishment is either life imprisonment or the same punishment as is imposed for second-degree murder.  Appellant
column7: after pleading not guilty to a murder indictment
column8: was convicted by a jury of first-degree murder and accordingly sentenced to life imprisonment.  The New Jersey Supreme Court affirmed
column9: rejecting appellant's contention that the possibility of a sentence of less than life upon the plea of non vult
column10: combined with the absence of a similar possibility when found guilty of first-degree murder by a jury
column11: was an unconstitutional burden on his rights under the Fifth
column13: and Fourteenth Amendments and also violated his right to equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.

column1: 1. The New Jersey sentencing scheme does not impose an unconstitutional burden on appellant's rights under the Fifth
column2: Sixth
column3: and Fourteenth Amendments.  Pp.  439 U. S. 216-225.

column1: (a) Although the mandatory punishment when a jury finds a defendant guilty of first-degree murder is life imprisonment
column2: the risk of that punishment is not completely avoided by pleading non vult because the judge accepting the plea has authority to impose a life term.  United States v. Jackson

column1: (b) Not every burden on the exercise of a constitutional right
column2: and not every pressure or encouragement to waive such a right
column3: is invalid; specifically
column4: there is no per se rule against encouraging guilty pleas.  Here
column5: the probability or certainty of leniency in return for a non vult plea did not invalidate the mandatory life sentence
column6: there having been no assurances that a plea would have been accepted and if it had been that a lesser sentence would have been imposed.  Cf. Bordenkircher v. Hayes

column1: (c) If appellant had tendered a plea and if it had been accepted and a term of years less than life had been imposed
column2: this would simply

column1: have recognized that there had been a plea
column2: and that
column3: in sentencing
column4: it is constitutionally permissible to take that fact into account.  Absent the abolition of guilty pleas and plea bargaining
column5: it is not forbidden under the Constitution to extend a proper degree of leniency in return for guilty pleas
column6: and New Jersey has done no more than that.  Pp.  439 U. S. 222-223.

column1: (d) There was no element of retaliation or vindictiveness against appellant for going to trial where it does not appear that he was subjected to unwarranted charges or was being punished for exercising a constitutional right.  While defendants pleading non vult may be treated more leniently than those who go to trial
column2: withholding the possibility of leniency from the latter cannot be equated with impermissible punishment as long as plea bargaining is held to be a proper procedure.  Pp.  439 U. S. 223-224.

column1: (e) The New Jersey sentencing scheme does not exert such a powerful influence to coerce inaccurate pleas non vult as to be deemed constitutionally suspect.  Here
column2: the State did not trespass on appellant's rights so long as he was free to accept or refuse the choice presented to him by the State
column3: i.e.
column4: to go to trial and face the risk of life imprisonment or to seek acceptance of a non vult plea and imposition of the lesser penalty.  P.  439 U. S. 225.

column1: 2. Nor does the sentencing scheme infringe appellant's right to equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment
column2: since all New Jersey defendants are given the same choice as to whether to go to trial or plead non vult.  Defendants found guilty by a jury are not penalized for exercising their right to a jury trial any more than defendants who plead guilty are penalized for giving up the chance of acquittal at trial.  Equal protection does not free those who made a bad assessment of risks or a bad choice from the consequences of their decision.  Pp.  439 U. S. 225-226.

column3: affirmed.

column1: Under the New Jersey homicide statutes
column2: life imprisonment is the mandatory punishment for defendants convicted by a jury of first-degree murder
column3: while a term of not more than 30 years is the punishment for second-degree murder.  Trials to the court and guilty pleas are not allowed in murder cases
column4: but a plea of non vult is allowed.  If such a plea is accepted
column5: the judge need not decide whether the murder is first or second degree
column6: but the punishment is either life imprisonment or the same punishment as is imposed for second-degree murder.  Appellant
column7: after pleading not guilty to a murder indictment
column8: was convicted by a jury of first-degree murder and accordingly sentenced to life imprisonment.  The New Jersey Supreme Court affirmed
column9: rejecting appellant's contention that the possibility of a sentence of less than life upon the plea of non vult
column10: combined with the absence of a similar possibility when found guilty of first-degree murder by a jury
column11: was an unconstitutional burden on his rights under the Fifth
column13: and Fourteenth Amendments and also violated his right to equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.

column1: 1. The New Jersey sentencing scheme does not impose an unconstitutional burden on appellant's rights under the Fifth
column2: Sixth
column3: and Fourteenth Amendments.  Pp.  439 U. S. 216-225.

column1: (a) Although the mandatory punishment when a jury finds a defendant guilty of first-degree murder is life imprisonment
column2: the risk of that punishment is not completely avoided by pleading non vult because the judge accepting the plea has authority to impose a life term.  United States v. Jackson

column1: (b) Not every burden on the exercise of a constitutional right
column2: and not every pressure or encouragement to waive such a right
column3: is invalid; specifically
column4: there is no per se rule against encouraging guilty pleas.  Here
column5: the probability or certainty of leniency in return for a non vult plea did not invalidate the mandatory life sentence
column6: there having been no assurances that a plea would have been accepted and if it had been that a lesser sentence would have been imposed.  Cf. Bordenkircher v. Hayes

column1: (c) If appellant had tendered a plea and if it had been accepted and a term of years less than life had been imposed
column2: this would simply

column1: have recognized that there had been a plea
column2: and that
column3: in sentencing
column4: it is constitutionally permissible to take that fact into account.  Absent the abolition of guilty pleas and plea bargaining
column5: it is not forbidden under the Constitution to extend a proper degree of leniency in return for guilty pleas
column6: and New Jersey has done no more than that.  Pp.  439 U. S. 222-223.

column1: (d) There was no element of retaliation or vindictiveness against appellant for going to trial where it does not appear that he was subjected to unwarranted charges or was being punished for exercising a constitutional right.  While defendants pleading non vult may be treated more leniently than those who go to trial
column2: withholding the possibility of leniency from the latter cannot be equated with impermissible punishment as long as plea bargaining is held to be a proper procedure.  Pp.  439 U. S. 223-224.

column1: (e) The New Jersey sentencing scheme does not exert such a powerful influence to coerce inaccurate pleas non vult as to be deemed constitutionally suspect.  Here
column2: the State did not trespass on appellant's rights so long as he was free to accept or refuse the choice presented to him by the State
column3: i.e.
column4: to go to trial and face the risk of life imprisonment or to seek acceptance of a non vult plea and imposition of the lesser penalty.  P.  439 U. S. 225.

column1: 2. Nor does the sentencing scheme infringe appellant's right to equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment
column2: since all New Jersey defendants are given the same choice as to whether to go to trial or plead non vult.  Defendants found guilty by a jury are not penalized for exercising their right to a jury trial any more than defendants who plead guilty are penalized for giving up the chance of acquittal at trial.  Equal protection does not free those who made a bad assessment of risks or a bad choice from the consequences of their decision.  Pp.  439 U. S. 225-226.

column2: the Board must disapprove a transaction that would
column3: inter alia
column4: generate anticompetitive effects not clearly outweighed by beneficial effects upon the acquired bank's ability to serve the community.  Section 3(c) also directs the Board ""[i]n every case"" to

column1: Individual stockholders who controlled an existing bank organized respondent corporation to acquire their bank stock.  Respondent submitted the transaction for the Board's approval.  Upon review
column2: the Board found that the transaction would have no anticompetitive effects and would not change the services offered by the bank to customers.  However

|439 u.s. 96|New Motor Vehicle Board of California v. Orrin W. Fox Co.

The California Automobile Franchise Act (Act) requires an automobile manufacturer to obtain approval of the California New Motor Vehicle Board (Board) before opening or relocating a retail dealership within the market area of an existing franchisee if the latter protests
column2: and the Act also directs the Board to notify the manufacturer of such requirement upon the existing franchisee's filing of a protest.  The Board is not required to hold a hearing on the merits of the protest before sending the notice to the manufacturer.  Appellee manufacturer and proposed new and relocated franchisees
column3: after being notified pursuant to the Act of protests from existing franchisees and before any hearings were held
column4: brought suit challenging the constitutionality of the statutory scheme on due process grounds.  A three-judge District Court held that the absence of a prior hearing requirement denied manufacturers and their proposed franchisees the procedural due process mandated by the Fourteenth Amendment.

column1: 1. The statutory scheme does not violate due process.  Pp.  439 U. S. 104-108.

(a) The Act does not have the effect of affording a protesting dealership a summary administrative adjudication in the form of a notice tantamount to a temporary injunction restraining the manufacturer's exercise of its right to franchise at will.  The Board's notice has none of the attributes of an injunction
column2: but serves only to inform the manufacturer of the statutory scheme and of the status
column3: pending the Board's determination
column4: of its franchise permit application.  Pp.  439 U. S. 104-105.

column1: (b) Nor can the Board's notice be characterized as an administrative order
column2: since it did not involve any exercise of discretion
column3: did not find or assume any adjudicative facts
column4: and did not terminate or suspend any right or interest that the manufacturer was then enjoying.  Fuentes v. Shevin
column5: 407 U. S. 67; Bell v. Burson

column1: (c) Even if the right to franchise constituted an interest protected by due process when the Act was enacted
column2: the California Legislature was still constitutionally empowered to enact a general scheme of business regulation that imposed reasonable restrictions upon the exercise of the right.  In particular
column3: the legislature was empowered to subordinate manufacturers' franchise rights to their franchisees' conflicting rights where necessary to prevent unfair or oppressive trade practices
column4: and also to protect franchisees' conflicting rights through customary and reasonable procedural safeguards
column5: i.e.

column1: |439 u.s. 1|"Long Island R.R. Co. v. Aberdeen & Rockfish Railroad Co.

The Interstate Commerce Commission initially denied petitioner railroad's request for an interim terminal surcharge to offset the increased taxes imposed by the Railroad Retirement Amendments of 1973 to fund additional retirement benefits for railroad employees.  But after a three-judge District Court set aside this denial and enjoined the ICC from refusing petitioner's terminal surcharge as an interim rate increase under  15a(6)(b) of the Interstate Commerce Act
column2: the ICC allowed an interim terminal surcharge.  On respondent railroads' petition to set aside the ICC's order
column3: the Court of Appeals directed that the interim surcharge be held in a separate trust fund pending the ICC's determination of final rates on remand.

column1: Held:  The Court of Appeals' imposition of the trust fund requirement is contrary to  15a(6)(b)'s purpose of providing an expeditious method of allowing higher rates in order to minimize the effect that the increased railroad retirement taxes would have on the railroads' financial condition.  Under  15a(6)(b)
column2: once the interim rates were filed
column3: the ICC could not suspend them until it made final rate determinations.  By impressing the trust on proceeds from these interim charges made by petitioner
column4: the Court of Appeals exercised authority that Congress did not repose even in the ICC.

column2: reversed in part and remanded.

The Medical School of the University of California at Davis (hereinafter Davis) had two admissions programs for the entering class of 100 students -- the regular admissions program and the special admissions program.  Under the regular procedure
column2: candidates whose overall undergraduate grade point averages fell below 2.5 on a scale of 4.0 were summarily rejected.  About one out of six applicants was then given an interview
column3: following which he was rated on a scale of 1 to 100 by each of the committee members (five in 1973 and six in 1974)
column4: his rating being based on the interviewers' summaries
column5: his overall grade point average
column6: his science courses grade point average
column7: his Medical College Admissions Test (MCAT) scores
column11: all of which resulted in a total ""benchmark score.""  The full admissions committee then made offers of admission on the basis of their review of the applicant's file and his score
column12: considering and acting upon applications as they were received.  The committee chairman was responsible for placing names on the waiting list and had discretion to include persons with ""special skills.""  A separate committee
column13: a majority of whom were members of minority groups
column14: operated the special admissions program.  The 1973 and 1974 application forms
column16: asked candidates whether they wished to be considered as ""economically and/or educationally disadvantaged"" applicants and members of a ""minority group"" (blacks
column19: American Indians).  If an applicant of a minority group was found to be ""disadvantaged
column20: he would be rated in a manner similar to the one employed by the general admissions committee.  Special candidates
column22: did not have to meet the 2.5 grade point cutoff and were not ranked against candidates in the general admissions process.  About one-fifth of the special applicants were invited for interviews in 1973 and 1974
column23: following which they were given benchmark scores
column24: and the top choices were then given to the general admissions committee
column25: which could reject special candidates for failure to meet course requirements or other specific deficiencies.  The special committee continued to recommend candidates until 16 special admission selections had been made.  During a four-year period

column1: students were admitted to Davis under the special program and 44 under the general program.  No disadvantaged whites were admitted under the special program
column2: though many applied.  Respondent
column3: a white male
column5: in both years being considered only under the general admissions program.  Though he had a 468 out of 500 score in 1973
column6: he was rejected
column7: since no general applicants with scores less than 470 were being accepted after respondent's application
column8: which was filed late in the year
column9: had been processed and completed.  At that time
column10: four special admission slots were still unfilled.  In 1974 respondent applied early
column11: and though he had a total score of 549 out of 600
column12: he was again rejected.  In neither year was his name placed on the discretionary waiting list.  In both years
column13: special applicants were admitted with significantly lower scores than respondent's.  After his second rejection
column14: respondent filed this action in state court for mandatory
column16: and declaratory relief to compel his admission to Davis
column17: alleging that the special admissions program operated to exclude him on the basis of his race in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment
column18: a provision of the California Constitution
column19: and  601 of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964
column22: that no person shall on the ground of race or color be excluded from participating in any program receiving federal financial assistance.  Petitioner cross-claimed for a declaration that its special admissions program was lawful.  The trial court found that the special program operated as a racial quota
column23: because minority applicants in that program were rated only against one another
column24: and 16 places in the class of 100 were reserved for them.  Declaring that petitioner could not take race into account in making admissions decisions
column25: the program was held to violate the Federal and State Constitutions and Title VI.  Respondent's admission was not ordered
column27: for lack of proof that he would have been admitted but for the special program.  The California Supreme Court
column29: concluded that the special admissions program was not the least intrusive means of achieving the goals of the admittedly compelling state interests of integrating the medical profession and increasing the number of doctors willing to serve minority patients.  Without passing on the state constitutional or federal statutory grounds
column30: the court held that petitioner's special admissions program violated the Equal Protection Clause.  Since petitioner could not satisfy its burden of demonstrating that respondent
column33: the court ordered his admission to Davis.

column1: Held:  The judgment below is affirmed insofar as it orders respondent's admission to Davis and invalidates petitioner's special admissions program
but is reversed insofar as it prohibits petitioner from taking race into account as a factor in its future admissions decisions.

column1: 1. Title VI proscribes only those racial classifications that would violate the Equal Protection Clause if employed by a State or its agencies.  Pp.  438 U. S. 281-287.

2. Racial and ethnic classifications of any sort are inherently suspect and call for the most exacting judicial scrutiny.  While the goal of achieving a diverse student body is sufficiently compelling to justify consideration of race in admissions decisions under some circumstances
column2: petitioner's special admissions program
column3: which forecloses consideration to persons like respondent
column4: is unnecessary to the achievement of this compelling goal
column5: and therefore invalid under the Equal Protection Clause.  Pp.  438 U. S. 287-320.

column1: 3. Since petitioner could not satisfy its burden of proving that respondent would not have been admitted even if there had been no special admissions program
column2: he must be admitted.  P.  438 U. S. 320.

column3: MR. JUSTICE MARSHALL

column1: 1. Title VI proscribes only those racial classifications that would violate the Equal Protection Clause if employed by a State or its agencies.  Pp.  438 U. S. 328-355.
2. Racial classifications call for strict judicial scrutiny.  Nonetheless
column2: the purpose of overcoming substantial
column3: chronic minority underrepresentation in the medical profession is sufficiently important to justify petitioner's remedial use of race.  Thus
column4: the judgment below must be reversed in that it prohibits race from being used as a factor in university admissions.  Pp.  438 U. S. 355-379.

column3: and sought to call witnesses to prove the misstatements.  The trial court sustained the State's objection to such proposed testimony and denied the motion to suppress
column4: and the clothing and knife were admitted as evidence at the ensuing trial
column5: at which petitioner was convicted.  The Delaware Supreme Court affirmed
column6: holding that a defendant under no circumstances may challenge the veracity of a sworn statement used by police to procure a search warrant.

column4: and if the allegedly false statement is necessary to the finding of probable cause

column1: Prior to petitioner's Delaware state trial on rape and related charges and in connection with his motion to suppress on Fourth Amendment grounds items of clothing and a knife found in a search of his apartment
column2: he challenged the truthfulness of certain factual statements made in the police affidavit supporting the warrant to search the apartment
column3: and sought to call witnesses to prove the misstatements.  The trial court sustained the State's objection to such proposed testimony and denied the motion to suppress
column4: and the clothing and knife were admitted as evidence at the ensuing trial
column5: at which petitioner was convicted.  The Delaware Supreme Court affirmed
column6: holding that a defendant under no circumstances may challenge the veracity of a sworn statement used by police to procure a search warrant.

column1: Held:  Where the defendant makes a substantial preliminary showing that a false statement knowingly and intentionally
column2: or with reckless disregard for the truth
column3: was included by the affiant in the warrant affidavit
column4: and if the allegedly false statement is necessary to the finding of probable cause
column5: the Fourth Amendment
column6: as incorporated in the Fourteenth Amendment
column7: requires that a hearing be held at the defendant's request.  The trial court here therefore erred in refusing to examine the adequacy of petitioner's proffer of misrepresentation in the warrant affidavit.  Pp.  438 U. S. 155-156;  438 U. S. 164-172.

column2: the challenger's attack must be more than conclusory
column3: and must be supported by more than a mere desire to cross-examine.  The allegation of deliberate falsehood or of reckless disregard must point out specifically with supporting reasons the portion of the warrant affidavit that is claimed to be false.  It also must be accompanied by an offer of proof
column4: including affidavits or sworn or otherwise reliable statements of witnesses
column5: or a satisfactory explanation of their absence.  P.  438 U. S. 171.

column1: (b) If these requirements as to allegations and offer of proof are met
column2: and if
column3: when material that is the subject of the alleged falsity or reckless disregard is set to one side
column4: there remains sufficient content in the warrant affidavit to support a finding of probable cause
column5: no hearing is required
column6: but if the remaining content is insufficient
column7: the defendant is entitled under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to a hearing.  Pp.  438 U. S. 171-172.

column2: after a hearing
column3: a defendant establishes by a preponderance of the evidence that the false statement was included in the affidavit by the affiant knowingly and intentionally
column4: or with reckless disregard for the truth
column5: and the false statement was necessary to the finding of probable cause
column6: then the search warrant must be voided
column7: and the fruits of the search excluded from the trial to the same extent as if probable cause was lacking on the face of the affidavit.  Pp. 155-156.

column2: reversed and remanded.

column2: and none is excluded from the definition of ""commerce"" at the outset; hence
column3: contrary to the suggestion of the court below

column6: distinguished.  Pp.  437 U. S. 621-623.

column1: (b) The crucial inquiry here must be directed to determining whether ch. 363 is basically an economic protectionist measure
column2: and thus virtually per se invalid
column3: or a law directed at legitimate local concerns that has only incidental effects on interstate commerce.   Pike v. Bruce Church

column1: (c) Since the evil of protectionism can reside in legislative means as well as legislative ends

column3: for
column5: it may not be accomplished by discriminating against articles of commerce coming from outside the State unless there is some reason
column6: apart from their origin
column7: to treat them differently.  Both on its face and in its plain effect

column9: as ch. 363 seeks to do by imposing on out-of-state commercial interests the full burden of conserving New Jersey's remaining landfill space.  Pp.  437 U. S. 625-628.

column8: promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (hereafter 1934 Act); and the Illinois Securities Act

column13: and joined therewith claims based on each of the other defensive counts made in the state court action.  American moved to dismiss or abate the federal court action

column15: and the motion to abate being on the ground that the earlier state proceeding included all issues except the one involving Rule 10b-5.  Petitioner

column1: Issuance of the writ of mandamus by the Court of Appeals impermissibly interfered with petitioner's discretion to control his docket.  Pp.  437 U. S. 661-667.
(a) Though a court of appeals has the power to issue a writ of mandamus directing a district court to proceed to judgment in a pending case when it is the district court's duty to do so
column2: the burden is on the moving party to show that its right to issuance of the writ is ""clear and indisputable.""  P.  437 U. S. 662.

column1: (b) Where there is duplicative litigation in the state and federal courts

column6: even when matters of federal law are involved

column3: did not involve outright dismissal of the action
column4: and respondent remained free to urge petitioner to reconsider his decision to defer based on new information as to the progress of the state case; to that extent

column3: it cannot be said that a litigant's right to a particular result is ""clear and indisputable.""  Here

column5: and
column6: as far as the record shows
column7: his delay in adjudicating that claim is simply the product of a district court's normal excessive workload
column8: compounded by ""the unfortunate consequence of making the judge a litigant"" in this mandamus proceeding.  Ex parte Fahey

column2: Government agents intercepted for a one-month period virtually all conversations over a particular telephone suspected of being used in furtherance of a conspiracy to import and distribute narcotics.  Forty percent of the calls were clearly narcotics related

column2: Inc. v. Virginia

column1: A Virginia statute makes it a crime to divulge information regarding proceedings before a state judicial review commission that is authorized to hear complaints about judges' disability or misconduct.  For printing in its newspaper an article accurately reporting on a pending inquiry by the commission and identifying the judge whose conduct was being investigated
column2: appellant publisher was convicted of violating the statute.  Rejecting appellant's contention that the statute violated the First Amendment as made applicable to the States by the Fourteenth
column3: the Virginia Supreme Court affirmed.

column1: Held:  The First Amendment does not permit the criminal punishment of third persons who are strangers to proceedings before such a commission for divulging or publishing truthful information regarding confidential proceedings of the commission.  Pp.  435 U. S. 837-845.
(a) A major purpose of the First Amendment is to protect the free discussion of governmental affairs
column2: which includes discussion of the operations of the courts and judicial conduct
column3: and the article published by appellant's newspaper served the interests of public scrutiny of such matters.  Pp.  435 U. S. 838-839.

column1: (b) The question is not whether the confidentiality of commission proceedings serves legitimate state interests
column2: but whether those interests are sufficient to justify encroaching on First Amendment guarantees that the imposition of criminal sanctions entails.  Injury to the reputation of judges or the institutional reputation of courts is not sufficient to justify ""repressing speech that would otherwise be free.""  New York Times Co. v. Sullivan

column1: (c) The mere fact that the legislature found a clear and present danger to the orderly administration of justice justifying enactment of the challenged statute did not preclude the necessity of proof that such danger existed.  This Court has consistently rejected the argument that out-of-court comments on pending cases or grand jury investigations constituted a clear and present danger to the administration of justice.  See Bridges v. California
column2: 314 U. S. 252; Pennekamp v. Florida
column3: 328 U. S. 331; Craig v. Harney
column5: 370 U. S. 375.  If the ""clear and present danger"" test could not be satisfied in those cases
column6: a fortiori it could not be satisfied here.  Pp.  435 U. S. 842-845.

column1: (d) Much of the risk to the orderly administration of justice can be eliminated through careful internal procedures to protect the confidentiality of commission proceedings.  P.  435 U. S. 845.

column3: reversed and remanded.

the case was submitted to a single Justice of the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts on an expedited basis and upon agreed facts.  Judgment was reserved
column4: and the case was referred to the full court.  On September 22

column1: 1. The case is not rendered moot by the fact that the 1976 referendum has been held and the proposal for a constitutional amendment defeated. column2: and likely would be too short in any future challenge to the statute; and in view of the number of times that such a proposal has been submitted to the electorate
column3: there is reasonable expectation that appellants again will be subjected to the threat of prosecution under the statute.  Weinstein v. Bradford

column2: namely
column3: the expression of views on an issue of public importance
column4: is at the heart of the First Amendment's concern.  There is no support in the First or Fourteenth Amendment
column5: or in this Court's decisions

column8: a material effect on its business.  Although appellee suggests that this Court's decisions generally have extended First Amendment rights only to corporations in the business of communications or which foster the self-expression of individuals
column9: those decisions were not based on the rationale that the challenged communication materially affected the company's business.  They were based
column11: on the Amendment's protection of public discussion and the dissemination of information and ideas.  Similarly
column12: commercial speech is accorded some constitutional protection not so much because it pertains to the seller's business as because it furthers the societal interest in the ""free flow of commercial information.""  Virginia State Bd. of Pharmacy v. Virginia Citizens Consumer Council

column1: (b) The asserted justifications for the challenged statute cannot survive the exacting scrutiny required when the legislative prohibition is directed at speech itself and speech on a public issue.  This statute cannot be justified by the State's asserted interest in sustaining the active role of the individual citizen in the electoral process and preventing diminution of his confidence in government.  Even if it were permissible to silence one segment of society upon a sufficient showing of imminent danger
column2: there has been no showing that the relative voice of corporations has been overwhelming or even significant in influencing referenda in Massachusetts
column3: or that there has been any threat to the confidence of the citizenry in government.  And the risk of corruption perceived in this Court's decisions involving candidate elections is not present in a popular vote on a public issue.  Nor can the statute be justified on the asserted ground that it protects the rights of shareholders whose views differ from those expressed by management on behalf of the corporation.  The statute is both underinclusive and overinclusive in serving this purpose
column4: and therefore could not be sustained even if the purpose itself were deemed compelling.  Pp.  435 U. S. 788-795.

a candidate for delegate to a Tennessee constitutional convention
column3: sued in the State Chancery Court for a declaratory judgment that appellant
column4: an opponent who was a Baptist minister
column5: was disqualified from serving as delegate by a Tennessee statutory provision establishing the qualifications of constitutional convention delegates to be the same as those for membership in the State House of Representatives
column6: thus invoking a Tennessee constitutional provision barring ""[m]inister[s] of the Gospel
column7: or priest[s] of any denomination whatever.""  That court held that the statutory provision violated the First and Fourteenth Amendments.  The Tennessee Supreme Court reversed
column8: holding that the clergy disqualification imposed no burden on ""religious belief

column1: religious action . . . [only] in the law making process of government -- where religious action is absolutely prohibited by the establishment clause. . . .""

column2: reversed and remanded.
joined by MR. JUSTICE POWELL
column3: MR. JUSTICE REHNQUIST
column5: concluded:

column1: 1. The Tennessee disqualification is directed primarily not at religious belief
column2: but at the status
column3: acts
column4: and conduct of the clergy.  Therefore
column5: the Free Exercise Clause's absolute prohibition against infringements on the ""freedom to believe"" is inapposite here.  Torcaso v. Watkins
column6: 367 U. S. 488 (which invalidated a state requirement that an appointee to public office declare his belief in the existence of God)

column2: the challenged provision violates appellant's First Amendment right to the free exercise of his religion made applicable to the States by the Fourteenth Amendment
column3: because it conditions his right to the free exercise of his religion on the surrender of his right to seek office.  Sherbert v. Verner
column5: 374 U. S. 406.  Though justification is asserted under the Establishment Clause for the statutory restriction on the ground that
column6: if elected to public office members of the clergy will necessarily promote the interests of one sect or thwart those of another contrary to the anti-establishment principle of neutrality
column7: Tennessee has failed to demonstrate that its views of the dangers of

column1: clergy participation in the political process have not lost whatever validity they may once have enjoyed.  Accordingly
column2: there is no need to inquire whether the State's legislative goal is permissible.  Pp.  435 U. S. 626;  435 U. S. 627-629.
joined by MR. JUSTICE MARSHALL
column3: concluded:

column1: 1. The Free Exercise Clause is violated by the challenged provision.  Pp.  435 U. S. 630-635.
(a) Freedom of belief protected by that Clause embraces freedom to profess or practice that belief
column2: even including doing so for a livelihood.  The Tennessee disqualification establishes as a condition of office the willingness to eschew certain protected religious practices.  The provision therefore establishes a religious classification governing eligibility for office that is absolutely prohibited.  Torcaso v. Watkins

column1: (b) The fact that the law does not directly prohibit religious exercise
column2: but merely conditions eligibility for office on its abandonment
column3: does not alter the protection afforded by the Free Exercise Clause.  ""Governmental imposition of such a choice puts the same kind of burden upon the free exercise of religion as would a fine . . .
column5: supra at  374 U. S. 404
column6: and Tennessee's disqualification provision therefore imposed an unconstitutional penalty on appellant's free exercise.  Moreover

column1: [t]he fact . . . that a person is not compelled to hold public office cannot possibly be an excuse for barring him from office by state-imposed criteria forbidden by the Constitution.""

column2: supra

column1: 2. The Tennessee disqualification also violates the Establishment Clause.  Government generally may not use religion as a basis of classification for the imposition of duties
column2: penalties
column3: privileges
column5: government may not fence out from political participation people such as ministers whom it regards as overinvolved in religion.  The disqualification provision employed by Tennessee here establishes a religious classification that has the primary effect of inhibiting religion.  Pp.  435 U. S. 636-642.

column2: supra
column3: controls this case.  Except for the fact that Tennessee bases its disqualification

column6: the situation in Torcaso is indistinguishable from the one here.  Pp.  435 U. S. 642-643.

column2: while not interfering with appellant's right to exercise his religion as he desires
column3: denies him equal protection.  Though that disqualification is based on the State's asserted interest in maintaining the required separation

column3: which all States except Tennessee have been able to realize without burdening ministers' rights to candidacy.  In addition

column1: The Court's action today lets stand the ruling by a panel of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals that attorneys' fees are awardable to intervenors in union election challenges processed under Title IV of the Labor Management Reporting and Disclosure Act (LMRDA)
column2: 29 U.S.C. 481 et seq. (1970). The issues presented in this case are of serious importance to the proper enforcement of the LMRDA
column3: and also to the prosecution generally of private claims that benefit a broad class of persons.

column1: The decision below rested on two necessary foundations: that the scheme of Title IV of the LMRDA did not foreclose the awarding of attorneys' fees to intervenors
column2: and that the ""common benefit"" exception to the American rule against awarding attorneys' fees could fairly be applied to a case of intervention under Title IV such as occurred here.

column1: In Trbovich v. United Mine Workers
column4: this Court held that intervention by an individual union member whose initial complaint commenced the challenge to the election was not inimical to the LMRDA. Title IV anticipates that objections to the conduct of union elections be initiated by union members filing a complaint with the Secretary of Labor after exhausting union remedies. Thereupon
column5: however
column6: it is the exclusive province of the Secretary to commence a civil action in federal district court. 29 U.S.C. 482(b). Trbovich held that the union member who initiated the challenge might still intervene in the federal suit
column7: ""so long as that intervention is limited to the claims of illegality presented

column2: supra
column4: at 537. This conclusion represented a very careful balance between Title IV's commitment of enforcement authority to the Secretary's sole discre ion
column5: and a recognition that the union member who originally raised the complaint might wish to see his claims pressed in some manner different from the Secretary.

column1: The opinion below threatens to upset that delicate compromise. Intervention by union members in support of the Secretary's grounds of complaint was upheld in Trbovich only because it would make the union liable ""to relatively little additional burden
column2: and would ""not subject the union to burdensome multiple litigation

column3: concluded that a criminal trial to a jury of less than six persons substantially threatens Sixth and Fourteenth Amendment guarantees. column1: |434 u.s. 452|"United States Steel Corp. v. Multistate Tax Commission

The Multistate Tax Compact was entered into by a number of States for the stated purposes of (1) facilitating proper determination of state and local tax liability of multistate taxpayers; (2) promoting uniformity and compatibility in state tax systems; (3) facilitating taxpayer convenience and compliance in the filing of tax returns and in other phases of tax administration; and (4) avoiding duplicative taxation.  To these ends
column2: the Compact created the appellee Multistate Tax Commission.  Each member State is authorized to request that the Commission perform an audit on its behalf
column3: and the Commission may seek compulsory process in aid of its auditing power in the courts of any State specifically permitting such procedure.  Individual States retain complete control over all legislative and administrative action affecting tax rates
column4: the composition of the tax base

column1: Appellants seek to appeal to this Court a decision of a three-judge District Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. 1253. That section provides for a direct appeal from any ""suit or proceeding required by any Act of Congress to be heard and determined by a district court of three judges."" If no Act of Congress required a three-judge District Court to hear this suit
column2: the decision cannot be appealed directly to this Court pursuant to 1253 even though a three-judge court may have been in fact convened. Appeal lies instead to the United States Court of Appeals. Under such circumstances we do not have jurisdiction to consider the appeal. Board of Regents v. New Left Education Project
387 U.S. 97 (1967); Phillips v. United States
column3: 312 U.S. 246 (1941 ). Because I believe that no Act of Congress required a three-judge District Court in this case
column4: I believe that the Court therefore errs in considering the merits of the appeal.

column2: officials of the California prison system

A three-judge court was convened under 28 U.S.C. 2281 (now repealed) which at the time this action was filed provided for such a court whenever the constitutionality of a ""State statute . . . or of an order made by an administrative board or commission acting under State statutes"" is challenged.

column1: It is the second clause of 2281 that is relevant here since appellees challenge no state statute. The District Court based its jurisdiction on a presumed challenge to various regulations promulgated and issued by the Director of the Department of Corrections of the State of California. According to the District Court
column2: these regulations are "" formal orders of statewide application"" and thus a challenge to their constitutionality provides jurisdiction under 2281. Both because the regulations would not appear to be ""order[s] made by an administrative board or commission"" and because appellees would not appear to challenge the regulations
column3: I do not believe that a three-judge District Court was required y 2281.

column1: An employer in the construction business made an agreement with respondent union under  8(f) of the National Labor Relations Act
column2: which provides that it shall not be an unfair labor practice for unions and employers in the construction
column3: industry to enter into ""prehire"" agreements before the majority status of the union has been established.  The contract contained no union security clause requiring employees to become union members within a specified period of time.  After the employer later undertook construction projects with nonunion labor
column4: the union picketed those projects (one for more than 30 days) with signs stating that the employer was violating the agreement with the union
column5: though the union did not represent a majority of the employees at the jobsites and had not petitioned for a representation election.  The employer then filed a charge with the National Labor Relations Board alleging that the union was violating  8(b)(7)(C) of the Act
column6: which makes it an unfair labor practice for an uncertified union to picket for the purpose of forcing an employer to recognize the union as a bargaining representative of his employees
column8: unless a petition for an election has been filed within that period.  The NLRB issued a cease and desist order in favor of the employer
column9: concluding that an object of the picketing was to force the employer to bargain with a union that was not currently certified as the representative of the employees working for the employer.  The Court of Appeals
column10: denying enforcement of the NLRB's order
column11: held that the validity of a  8(f) prehire contract conferred the right to enforce the contract by picketing as well as the right
column13: to file and prevail on an unfair labor practice charge against the employer for failure to bargain.

column1: Held:  Respondent's picketing was for recognitional purposes
column2: and constituted an unfair labor practice under  8(b)(7)(C).  An uncertified union like respondent
column3: which does not represent a majority of the employees
column4: may not under that provision engage in picketing in an effort to enforce a prehire agreement with the employer.  Pp.  434 U. S. 341-352.

column2: which contains a proviso clause that a ""prehire"" contract shall not bar a petition for an election under  9(c)
column3: was not intended to relieve a union party to a prehire agreement from the obligation to achieve majority support before it can require the employer to honor such an agreement by means of  8(a)(5)
column4: or to accord the union the status of bargaining representative that would exempt it from the recognitional picketing prohibition of  8(b)(7).  The NLRB therefore correctly held that
column5: when the union picketed to enforce its prehire agreement
column6: the employer could file and prevail on a  8(b)(7) charge
column7: because the union lacked majority credentials at the picketed projects.  Picketing to enforce the  8(f) contract was tantamount to recognitional picketing
column8: and  8(b)(7)(C) was infringed when the union failed to request an election within 30 days.  Pp.  434 U. S. 342-346.

column1: (b) Because  8(b)(7) was adopted to ensure employees the voluntary
column2: uncoerced selection of a bargaining representative
column3: the NLRB did not err in holding that that provision applies to a minority union's picketing to enforce a prehire contract.  Nor does the NLRB's position
column4: which is entitled to considerable deference
column5: render  8(f) meaningless
column6: since
column8: neither party could execute a prehire agreement without committing an unfair labor practice
column9: and the voluntary observance of an otherwise valid  8(f) contract is left unchallenged.  Retail Clerks v. Lion Dry Goods
column11: 369 U. S. 17; Building & Construction Trades Council of Santa Barbara County (Sullivan Electric Co.)

column3: and under  307(b)(2) such action is not subject to judicial review in a civil or criminal enforcement proceeding.  Petitioner was indicted for violating  112(c)(1)(b) for allegedly having failed while demolishing a building to comply with an EPA regulation captioned ""National Emission Standard for Asbestos"" and specifying that a certain procedure or ""work practice"" be followed in demolition of buildings containing asbestos but not limiting asbestos emissions that occur during a demolition. column5: granted petitioner's motion to dismiss the indictment.  The Court of Appeals reversed
column6: holding that  307(b) precluded petitioner from questioning in a criminal enforcement proceeding whether a regulation ostensibly promulgated under  112(c) was in fact an emission standard.
